profileText: A Representative from Vermont; born in Rutland, Rutland County, Vt., August 16, 1810; was graduated from Middlebury (Vt.) College in 1832; taught in the seminary at Castleton, Vt., and in the local academy at St. Albans, Vt.; attended Andover (Vt.) Theological Seminary, where he studied for the ministry and was ordained as a Congregational minister in 1838, assuming his duties as pastor in New Haven, Vt., and served from 1839 to 1846; tutor and professor at Middlebury College 1846-1850; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-first Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of George P. Marsh; reelected as a Whig to the Thirty-second and Thirty-third Congresses, and elected as an Opposition Party candidate to the Thirty-fourth Congress and served from December 3, 1849, until his death in Rutland, Vt., August 23, 1856; chairman, Committee on District of Columbia (Thirty-fourth Congress); interment in West Cemetery, Middlebury, Vt.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of George P. Marsh, and took his seat December 3, 1849.

researchRecord.name: In the Peter Force papers, 1825-1856, 6 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include a letter of introduction from George Perkins Marsh, 1849 September 5, on behalf of James Meacham, his successor as representative from Vermont.

recordLocation.name: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library

researchRecord.name: 1817-1856. 1 foot.
researchRecord.description: Personal and business papers and photographs, including letters related to major political issues, most notably the Kansas-Nebraska Act. Includes one letter to William Slade and one to Jacob Collamer. Finding aid in repository.
